However, the critiques of the highest forecasts (68–77%) convincingly pointed out the limiting effects of the short time window, the psychological and technical significance of $180 support, and the market’s efficiency in pricing expected volatility. Weighing these perspectives, I judge the risk is somewhat greater than my initial estimate but not as high as the 50%+ camp. I am therefore revising my probability moderately upward to reflect a slightly higher risk of a post-earnings breach, especially on the downside, but still below the median group estimate.

Portfolio Management (Quantitative Inves.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group's probabilities and arguments, especially the critiques and defenses, my initial estimate of 44% remains close to the consensus of informed, volatility-aware forecasters but is below the highest estimates (>70%) and above the lowest (<20%). question_details.title: Will NVIDIA's stock price close above $220 or below $180 on any single day before November 22, 2025?
question_details.description:
Yahoo Finance:[ Citi Raises Nvidia Price Target to \$720 Ahead of Earnings](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/citi-raises-nvidia-price-target-172458877.html)

> Nvidia (NVDA, Financials) just got another confidence boost from Wall Street. Ahead of its upcoming earnings report, Citi Research raised its price target on the AI chip leader to \$720 from \$650, saying demand for Nvidia's processors remains as strong as ever.

> Citi's analysts called Nvidia the undisputed leader in artificial intelligence computing a title it has earned thanks to relentless demand for its H100 chips and growing excitement over its next-generation Blackwell GPUs. Those products are expected to power data centers well into 2026 as companies race to expand their AI infrastructure.

Nvidia's earnings report is [scheduled](https://investor.nvidia.com/events-and-presentations/events-and-presentations/default.aspx) for November 19, 2025. 

A 1-year spreadsheet of Nvidia's stock price can be found [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1LATfewMDYYiAsAoGX370hKCd_yt6TuVJwOk_qoJPjH8/edit?gid=0#gid=0).

question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if Nvidia’s stock closes at greater than or equal to \$220.00 or less than or equal to \$180.00 for any regular trading day after November 10, 2025 and before November 22, 2025, according to [<u>Yahoo Finance</u>](https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/NVDA/history/) or (if necessary) alternative [<u>credible sources</u>](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions).
question_details.fine_print: If there is a stock split or similar price adjustment, the resolution value will adjust to account for the split. Typically this is done by multiplying forward split prices by the split factor to align them with pre-split values and dividing reverse split prices by the split factor.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Prediction: The Puzzle Pieces Are in Place for Nvidia to Disappoint Wall Street on Nov. 19**
Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) is set to release its fiscal 2026 third-quarter earnings on Wednesday, November 19, following the market close. While Wall Street expects the company to significantly exceed consensus sales and profit forecasts, the article argues that several factors suggest a potential disappointment. Nvidia's dominance in the AI-graphics processing unit (GPU) market—where it is estimated to control over 90% of AI-GPU deployments in high-compute data centers—stems from its superior hardware and GPU scarcity. CEO Jensen Huang has maintained an aggressive innovation cycle, aiming to launch a new advanced GPU annually, with the Hopper, Blackwell, and Blackwell Ultra generations establishing a clear performance lead. However, despite these strong competitive advantages, the article posits that 'the puzzle pieces are in place for the company to disappoint investors,' implying that even with its market leadership, the risk of underperformance remains due to market expectations and potential unforeseen challenges. The company recently became the first publicly traded firm to reach a $5 trillion market capitalization, driven by the multitrillion-dollar opportunity in artificial intelligence.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 14, 2025 06:10 PM
Source:[Yahoo! Finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/prediction-puzzle-pieces-place-nvidia-080600742.html)

**Morgan Stanley Doubles Bullish Nvidia Bet, Raises Price Target to $220 Ahead of Earnings**
Morgan Stanley has doubled its bullish stance on Nvidia by raising its price target from $210 to $220, just days before the company's crucial third-quarter earnings report on November 19, 2025. The upgrade is based on three pillars identified by Wall Street's top semiconductor analyst, Joseph Moore: accelerating demand for Nvidia's Blackwell chips, a cleaner supply chain, and what Moore calls 'convex profit leverage,' where profit growth accelerates faster than revenue due to improving operational efficiency. Moore expects 'the strongest results we've seen in recent quarters' for Nvidia's Q3 earnings, with analyst estimates forecasting revenue of approximately $54.8 billion—though actual results could exceed expectations. Forward guidance for Q4 is projected at around $61 billion, but Morgan Stanley believes this may also be conservative if Blackwell adoption continues to accelerate. Supply chain constraints from TSMC's advanced packaging and SK Hynix's high-bandwidth memory (HBM) have eased, enabling Nvidia to convert pent-up demand into actual shipments. Moore also highlighted 'very strong' signals for Nvidia's upcoming Rubin platform, set for launch in 2026 and expected to be 3.3 times faster than Blackwell, suggesting long-term enterprise AI demand will sustain multi-year revenue growth. Despite Nvidia's current valuation of around 30x expected earnings, Morgan Stanley argues the high multiple is justified by scale and profitability potential. The $220 target implies only 15-20% upside from current levels, but the firm's confidence in execution—backed by due diligence and internal validation—signals that Nvidia's next chapter is just beginning. The move underscores Morgan Stanley's belief that the company will not miss its earnings targets, even amid market concerns about AI hype and diminishing returns on AI investments. The timing of the price target increase before earnings demonstrates a high degree of conviction.

**Morgan Stanley Raises Nvidia Price Target to $220 Ahead of Earnings, Citing Accelerating Blackwell Demand and Supply Chain Improvements**
Morgan Stanley raised its price target for Nvidia from $210 to $220 ahead of the company's earnings report on November 19, 2025, citing a major inflection point in Nvidia's activity that the market has overlooked. The firm's lead semiconductor analyst, Joseph Moore, emphasized three pillars for the updated bullish scenario: accelerated demand for the Blackwell chip architecture, a cleaner supply chain, and a 'convex leverage on profits'—where profit growth outpaces revenue growth due to improving operational efficiency. Internal checks reveal that Blackwell adoption is progressing faster than consensus expectations, with Moore predicting 'the strongest result we've seen in recent quarters.' While analysts forecast third-quarter revenue of approximately $54.8 billion, Moore suggests the actual figure could exceed expectations. Fourth-quarter revenue is projected at around $61 billion, but Morgan Stanley believes even this could be conservative if Blackwell adoption accelerates further. Supply chain constraints from TSMC’s advanced packaging and SK Hynix’s high-bandwidth memory (HBM) have eased, enabling Nvidia to convert pent-up demand into actual shipments. Moore also highlighted 'very strong' signals for Nvidia’s upcoming Rubin platform, set for launch in 2026 and expected to be 3.3 times faster than Blackwell, indicating sustained long-term demand. Enterprise AI clients are locking in capacity, creating multi-year revenue streams that justify Nvidia’s high valuation. Although critics argue Nvidia is overvalued at around 30 times forward earnings, Morgan Stanley’s $220 target implies only a 15–20% upside from current levels, which the firm considers restrained for a growth stock. The firm’s confidence stems from verified due diligence, asserting that fundamentals are accelerating, not slowing. By raising the target before earnings, Morgan Stanley is betting its credibility on Nvidia’s continued execution. The message is clear: Nvidia’s next chapter is just beginning, and the November 19 report will confirm it.

**Nvidia Reports Earnings Next Week. How Big of a Blowout Will It Be?**
Nvidia (NVDA) is set to report its third-quarter earnings after market close on November 19, 2025, with Wall Street forecasting $54.83 billion in revenue—representing a 56% year-over-year increase—and $1.25 in adjusted earnings per share, up 54% year-over-year. The company has beaten earnings estimates 90% of the time over the past five years, though the average beat in the last four quarters was only 6.5%, likely due to improved analyst forecasting. Nvidia's dominance in AI chips, particularly in data centers, continues to drive growth, fueled by demand from hyperscalers like Microsoft (MSFT) and Meta Platforms (META), as well as the ramp-up of Blackwell chips and software integrations like CUDA. Revenue is expected to benefit from strong data center demand and diversified growth via platforms such as Omniverse, with recent deals including Oracle (ORCL) for cloud AI infrastructure. However, Nvidia expects no revenue from H20 chip sales to China in Q3 due to ongoing U.S. export restrictions. 'Whisper numbers' suggest the market expects a larger-than-forecasted beat, and any miss could trigger a selloff, given Nvidia’s role as a bellwether for the broader AI sector.

**Citi Raises Nvidia (NVDA) Target to $220 and Opens Positive Catalyst Watch**
NVIDIA Corporation (NASDAQ: NVDA) has been upgraded by Citi, which raised its price target to $220 per share from $210 and maintained a 'Buy' rating. The firm opened a positive catalyst watch ahead of NVDA's third-quarter earnings announcement on November 19, 2025, forecasting 'beat and raise' results. Analyst Atif Malik revised his Q4 2025 sales estimate to $57 billion, above the Street consensus of ~$55 billion, and expects Q1 2026 guidance of $62 billion versus ~$61 billion. Citi cited Nvidia's strong AI demand, noting the company has already shipped 6 million Blackwell units, as a key driver. The firm also raised its 2028 data center semiconductors total addressable market forecast to $654 billion, up 16% from $563 billion. Citi views NVDA’s current P/E of 28x as attractive compared to peers AVGO (38x) and AMD (37x). NVIDIA specializes in AI-driven platforms for data centers, self-driving vehicles, robotics, and cloud services. While Citi remains positive, the article notes that other AI stocks may offer greater upside and lower downside risk, particularly those benefiting from Trump-era tariffs and onshoring trends.

**Nvidia’s Upcoming Earnings: A $4 Trillion Question on AI Supply Chain and Energy Capacity**
Nvidia is set to release its fiscal 2026 third-quarter financial results on November 19, 2025, with Wall Street closely watching the report. The company reported $54 billion in revenue, a 54% year-over-year increase, driven primarily by surging demand for data center chips from hyperscalers building AI infrastructure. This single quarterly report is expected to shape not only Nvidia’s trajectory but also the entire AI supply chain—from chipmakers and memory suppliers to cloud service providers and energy companies. The Blackwell architecture, Nvidia’s next-generation GPU platform, is central to investor expectations, with projections for Blackwell revenues rising from $3–4 billion in 2025 to nearly $56 billion in 2026. However, production constraints persist, particularly in advanced CoWoS packaging by TSMC and high-bandwidth memory (HBM) supply from SK hynix and Samsung, both of which are oversubscribed through at least mid-2026. These bottlenecks are cascading through the supply chain, causing secondary market premiums and disrupting deployment plans. Geopolitical factors add complexity: U.S. export controls on AI chips to China have led Nvidia to develop downgraded versions like the H20, while Chinese hyperscalers increasingly turn to domestic alternatives like Huawei and Biren, fragmenting the global AI chip ecosystem. Energy demand is another critical constraint—Nvidia and OpenAI plan for 10 gigawatts of AI data center capacity, equivalent to 16% of projected new U.S. electricity generation in 2025. However, utilities from Silicon Valley to Northern Virginia are unable to keep pace, leaving data centers like those from Digital Realty and Stack Infrastructure idle until 2027 or 2028. Investors will closely monitor CEO Jensen Huang’s comments on power capacity and the upcoming Rubin architecture, expected in 2026 and potentially 3.3 times faster than Blackwell. Analysts forecast fourth-quarter revenue at around $61 billion; exceeding this could signal sustained AI momentum, while falling short may deflate the AI boom’s momentum. The earnings call is not just about Nvidia’s numbers—it’s a pivotal moment for assessing whether the AI boom can maintain its rapid pace.

**Nvidia poised for more gains as AI demand continues to accelerate, says Morgan Stanley**
Morgan Stanley has raised its expectations for several major chip manufacturers, citing the continued strength in demand for artificial intelligence (AI) that is accelerating both in supply and customer pipelines. Analyst Joseph Moore reiterated his optimistic view on Nvidia and Broadcom, and modestly raised his expectations for Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), highlighting optimism for the second half of the year as the AI sector continues to grow at an accelerated rate. Nvidia sees a boost before the launch of the Blackwell, with Moore raising his price target for the stock to $170 to $200, implying a 14% increase from Tuesday's close. The analyst maintained his 'overweight' rating and pointed to strong trends both in supply and demand. 'The strength of AI is exceptional both in supply and demand. All our data points and contacts are telling us that customers need more computing,' Moore observed in his report. He also emphasized an acceleration in inference workloads, which has become a key factor in the use of chips as more AI models move to deployment phases. Moore sees a significant advantage in the second half of the year, largely driven by the upcoming Blackwell product cycle, which includes next-generation processors, as well as improvements in connectivity, network, and memory solutions. The stock has already risen nearly 31% this year. In early July, the company announced that it will begin deliveries of its H20 general-purpose GPUs (GPUs) to China 'soon', after export-related issues. In April, Nvidia said it would accept a quarterly charge of $5.5 billion due to export restrictions to China, but the resumption of some product flows appears to be a new favorable wind. The stock has risen 26% this year so far. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) has surpassed Nvidia so far in 2025, with a year-to-date gain of 47%. Although Moore maintained a 'neutral' rating on AMD, he raised his price target from $121 to $185, signaling potential for more than 4% additional upside. 'The restoration of products to the Chinese market has added a new favorable wind for AMD/NVDA in the second half,' wrote Moore. He expressed optimism about the AMD's Mi350 product cycle, which he believes will offer significant advantages as cloud infrastructure providers continue to increase spending. Although Moore favors Nvidia as the primary beneficiary of the increased investment in AI, AMD is positioned to capture incremental gains from the broader increase in demand and new opportunities available in the Chinese market. Broadcom (NASDAQ: AVGO) also received an optimistic update from Moore, who raised his price target from $270 to $338, representing more than 13% increase from current levels. He reiterated a 'overweight' rating for the stock, which has already advanced more than 28% this year. Unlike Nvidia and AMD, whose gains are largely tied to processors, it is expected that Broadcom will benefit from the AI boom through the network segment. Moore stated that the company's advantage would come 'primarily from the network side, not from processors,' reflecting the critical role of data transfer and bandwidth optimization in large-scale AI systems. As investments in AI by cloud providers and companies expand, Moore believes that the broader semiconductor sector will have continued strength in the second half of the year, with Nvidia, AMD, and Broadcom among the biggest beneficiaries.

summary:
Forecasters provided a broad range of estimates for the probability that Nvidia's stock will close above $220 or below $180 on any single day before November 22, 2025, during a crucial earnings week. All experts agree that the outcome hinges on the November 19 earnings release, which is historically a high-volatility event for Nvidia, especially given the company's pivotal role in the AI sector and sky-high market expectations. 

Most experts cited the following key factors that could drive a break of the $180/$220 boundaries: 
- Extreme volatility surrounding earnings for high-profile, high-growth stocks like Nvidia. 
- Consensus bullishness and analyst price targets clustered around $220 or higher, which could trigger an upside break if earnings greatly exceed expectations, or a sharp downside move if results disappoint.
- Recent price levels (last close ~$186.86) and historical ability of NVDA to move >10% in a day post-earnings, putting both thresholds within reach.
- Options market positioning, which could amplify price moves via gamma hedging or stop-loss cascades.
- Short time window (6 trading days), which slightly tempers probabilities unless the move happens in direct response to a major surprise.

Most forecasters see an upside breach ($220+) as more challenging due to the large percentage move needed (about 18% up), but analysts note the downside ($180-) is quite close (~4% down) and thus more easily triggered if there is negative news. Consensus attributes more risk to the downside if Nvidia fails to meet the very high market bar.

Probabilities estimated by the experts range from as low as 19% to as high as 77%. 
- EMH, fundamental valuation, and technical analysts tend to place the probability in the 19–44% range, emphasizing recent trading ranges, efficient pricing, and the need for a strong catalyst.
- Market structure, behavioral finance, microstructure, and machine learning experts are notably higher—especially behavioral and machine learning practitioners (68–77%)—emphasizing past extreme moves, herd behavior, and the potential for sharp order flow imbalances around an event as high-profile as Nvidia's earnings.
- The group generally acknowledges that while base rates for large-cap stocks experiencing such outsized moves are not high in an ordinary week, the unique moment of an earnings event, coupled with exceptional hype and expectation, meaningfully raises tail risk above the average base rate.

Typical 'no' scenarios involve Nvidia reporting in-line or slightly above/below expectations, with price action contained in the recent range by anchoring to analyst targets and technical support/resistance. 'Yes' scenarios revolve around a significant earnings/guidance beat or miss, or a macro/market shock that triggers either panic selling or euphoric buying.

In summary, experts agree the risk of a breach is meaningfully elevated in this unique window due to the confluence of extreme event risk, expectations, and volatility—most estimate the chance of a close >$220 or <$180 to be moderate to high, with the most common range across experts falling between 30% and 77%, and consensus centering on the view that a single outsized post-earnings move is plausible but not guaranteed.
